Hdt. 2.127; αἱμασιὴν ὕψος ἀνήκουσαν ἀνδρὶ ἐς τὸν ὀμφαλόν Id. 7.60; ἐς τὰ μέγιστα ἀ. ἀρετῆς πέρι 5.49; χρήμασι ἀ. ἐς τὰ πρῶτα 7.134; φρενῶν ἐς τὰ ἐμεωυτοῦ πρῶτα οὔκω ἀ. have not yet reached the highest point I aim at, ib. 13; οὐκ ἐς τοσοῦτο εὐηθίης ἀ. ib. 16.γ, cf. 9.γ; πρόσω ἀρετῆς ἀ. ib. 237; ἀ. εἰς τὸ ὀξύ to rise to a point, Ael. NA 1.55; τοῦτο μὲν ἐς οὐδὲν ἀ. amounts to nothing, Hdt. 2.104; μεῖζον ἀ. ἢ κατʼ ἐμὰν ῥώμαν the matter has gone too far . ., S. Tr. 1018; αἱ πολλαὶ [ζημίαι] . . ἐς τὸν θάνατον ἀ. have gone as far as . ., Th. 3.45.

data.quote: αἱμασιὴν ὕψος ἀνήκουσαν ἀνδρὶ ἐς τὸν ὀμφαλόν
ἐς τὰ μέγιστα ἀ. ἀρετῆς πέρι
αἱ πολλαὶ [ζημίαι] . . ἐς τὸν θάνατον ἀ.

children.definition: ἀ. ἐς σὲ ἔχειν it has come to you to have, has become yours to have, Hdt. 6.109.

ἀ. εἴς τι refer to or be connected with . ., D. 60.6, Arist. EN 1167b4 (v.l.); τὰ εἰς ἀργυρίου λόγον ἀ. ἀδικήματα which involve a money consideration, Din. 1.60; so ὁ φόνος ἀνήκει εἴς τινα Antipho 3.3.7; ἀ. πρός τι Plb. 2.15.4, Callix. 2, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: belong, appertain, LXX 1 Ma. 10.42, al.; τὰ εἰς τιμὴν καὶ δόξαν ἀνήκοντα OGI 763.36 (Pergam.); τὰ ἐκείνοις -οντα ib. 532 (Paphlag.); τὰ ἀ. τῇ πόλει Inscr.Magn. 53.65 (iii B. C.); τὰ ἀ. τοῖς ἱεροῖς PTeb. 6.42 (ii B. C.).

data.quote: τὰ εἰς τιμὴν καὶ δόξαν ἀνήκοντα

children.definition: to be fit or proper, Ep.Eph. 5.4, Ep.Col. 3.18; τὸ ἀνῆκον, = τὸ προσῆκον, Ep.Philem. 8.

children.label: III
children.definition: come back, εἰς τοὺς πρώτους πάλιν ἀ. λόγους Pl. Tht. 196b.

data.quote: εἰς τοὺς πρώτους πάλιν ἀ. λόγους

children.definition: unable to spin, γυνή Matro Parod.Fr. 5.
not malleable, Arist. Mete. 385a16: metaph., stubborn, Anacr. 140.
not struck with a hammer, LXX Jb. 41.15.
unconcerned, reckless, πόλεμος Q.S. 2.75: neut. in Hsch. Adv. -έως Q.S. 2.414.

without pity, unmerciful, Men. Epit. 478, Call. Del. 106, Parth. 14.2, App. Mith. 38; poet. acc. ἀνηλέα (as if from ἀνηλής) Epigr.Gr. 418 ( Cyrene); gen. ἀνηλέος Man. 1.263; ἀνηλής is dub. in Alcm. 81, cf. An.Ox. 1.60. Adv. -εῶς Hp. Aff. 40, And. 4.39.
unpitied, Lycurg. 148 ( ἀνελ- codd.).

children.label: II
children.definition: unmerciful, Aeschin. 2.163, Eub. 1 D. Adv. -τως Pl. Lg. 697d, Ar. Fr. 51D.
unanointed, should be read for ἀνείληπτος in Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.13.19:—also ἀνήλειφος (so codd.) or ἀνήλῐφος, ον, D.C. 56.30, Philagr. ap. Orib. 5.19.10, Hp. Ep. 17.
being unanointed, uncleanliness, Hp. Vict. 2.57, Plb. 3.87.2.
place in the sun, f.l. in Protagorid. 4.
not yet arrived at manʼs estate, Ps.-Callisth. 1.38, Suid. s.v. ἄνηβος.

definition: ἀνηλιοδείκτης, ου, ὁ, dub. sens. in PMag.Par. 1.1374.

children.definition: without sun, unsunned, sunless, of the nether world, A. Th. 859 (lyr.); μυχοί, δνόφοι, Id. Pr. 453, Ch. 51 (lyr.); φυλλάς S. OC 676 (lyr.); λιβάς E. Andr. 534 (lyr.).
barefoot and unanointed (?), Epigr. ap. Hegesand. 1.
barefoot, v.l. for νήλιπος, Theoc. 4.56.
Suid.: ἀνήλῐφος, ον, v. ἀνήλειπτος.
going up: return, Hsch.
PTeb. 212 (ii B. C.), PHal. 15.7 (iii B. C.), BGU 1117.15 (i B. C.), IG 2.595, etc.
PLond. 2.265.10 (i A. D.); ἀ. μέτρον PPetr. 3p.317.
not nailed, Suid. s.v. ἀγόμφωτος.
unmilked, Od. 9.439.

not tame, wild, savage, of persons, πολιήτας Anacr. 1.7; ἀνήμεροι γάρ, οὐδὲ πρόσπλατοι ξένοις A. Pr. 716, cf. Carneisc. Herc. 1027.16, 2 Ep.Ti. 3.3, Arr. Epict. 1.3.7; of a country, A. Eu. 14; ἐκβολή E. Hec. 1078; βίος Plu. Util. 2.86d; διάθεσις Phld. Ir. p.57 W., cf. p.85: Sup., Clearch. 37. Adv. -ρως, ἀ. τισὶ χρήσασθαι D.S. 13.23.
wildness, savageness, Phld. Oec. p.68 J., Gloss.
to clear of wild beasts, ἀ. κνωδάλων ὁδόν S. Fr. 905.
untilled, γῆ S. Fr. 825, Cratin. 26 D.
not torn or lacerated, Hsch.
AP 9.544 ( Adaeus); noted as an archaic form by Luc. Pseudol. 29.
without wind, ἀνήνεμος χειμώνων without the blast of storms, S. OC 677 (lyr.); gentle, τυφών Olymp. in Mete. 201.22.
unbridled, EM 107.20.
without pain, Hp. ap. Gal. 19.81.

definition: ἀνήνοθε, Ep. pf. used like an aor.: αἷμʼ ἔτι θερμὸν ἀνήνοθεν ἐξ ὠτειλῆς blood

children.definition: gushed forth from the wound, Il. 11.266; κνίση ὲν ἀνήνοθεν the savour mounted up, Od. 17.270 ( ἐνήνοθε Aristarch.).
of none effect, ineffectual, ἀνηνύστῳ ἐπὶ ἔργῳ Od. 16.111, cf. A.R. 4.1307; κάματοι Opp. C. 4.196.
impossible of fulfilment, Emp. 12.
Pl. Lg. 735b, 936c; ἀ. ἔργον πράττειν, of Penelopeʼs web, Id. Phd. 84a, cf. E. Hel. 1285. Adv., ταῦτʼ ἀνηνύτως ἔχει S. Fr. 557.4.
endless, never-ending, οἶτος Id. El. 167, cf. Plb. 9.24.4; κακόν Pl. Grg. 507e; κακοπαθία Phld. Herc. 1251.17; βυθός, etc., Ph. 1.85, etc.: neut. pl. as Adv., ἀνήνυτα μοχθοῦσιν Epicur. Fr. 470.
unmanly, Od. 10.301; ἀνὴρ ἀνήνωρ a man of no manhood, Hes. Op. 751.

children.label: II
children.definition: childless, Hsch.

definition: ἀνηπλωμένως, Adv. pf. part. Pass. of ἀναπλόω,

children.definition: at length, in detail, opp. συνῃρημένως, τὸν λόγον παραδίδωσι Simp. in Ph. 1215.20; ἀ. καὶ ἀφηγηματικῶς Aps. p. 348 S.
unheard of, dub. in Zonar.
sound, αὐλοῦ ἦχον ἀνηπύοντος Mosch. 2.98.
sing aloud, ὑμέναιον A.R. 4.1197.

definition: ἀνήρ, ὁ, ἀνδρός, ἀνδρί, ἄνδρα, voc. ἄνερ: pl. ἄνδρες, -δρῶν, -δράσι [ᾰ], -δρας: Aeol. dat. pl. ἄνδρεσι Alc. Supp. 14.8: late nom. sg. ἄνδρας Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.109.7: in Att. the Art. often forms a crasis with the Noun, ἁνήρ for ὁ ἀνήρ, τἀνδρός, τἀνδρί for τοῦ ἀνδρός, etc., ἅνδρες for οἱ ἄνδρες; the Ion. crasis is ὡνήρ, ὧνδρες, Hdt. 4.161, 134: Ep. also ἀνέρα, ἀνέρος, ἀνέρι, dual ἀνέρε, pl. ἀνέρες, ἀνέρας, ἄνδρεσσι. [ Ep. Poets mostly use ᾱ in arsi, ᾰ in thesi; but in trisyll. forms with stem ἀνέρ- always ᾱ; so also Trag. in lyr., S. Tr. 1011, OT 869. But in Trag. senarians ᾰ always.] ( ἀ- in nom. by analogy; cf. Skt. nar- from I.-E. ner-, nṛ- from nṛ-, Gk. ἀνδρ- from ṇr-):—

children.definition: man, opp. woman ( ἄνθρωπος being man as opp. to beast), Il. 17.435, Od. 21.323; τῶν ἀνδρῶν ἄπαις without male children, Pl. Lg. 877e; in Hom. mostly of princes, leaders, etc., but also of free men; ἀ. δήμου one of the people, Il. 2.198, cf. Od. 17.352; with a qualifying word to indicate rank, ἀ. βουληφόρος Il. 2.61; ἀ. βασιλεύς Od. 24.253; ἡγήτορες ἄ. Il. 11.687.

children.label: II
children.definition: man, opp. god, πατὴρ ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε ib. 1.544, al.; Διὸς ἄγγελοι ἠδὲ καὶ ἀνδρῶν ib. 334, cf. 403, Hdt. 5.63, etc.: most common in pl., yet sts. in sg., e.g. Il. 18.432:—freq. with a Noun added, βροτοί, θνητοὶ ἄ., Od. 5.197, 10.306; ἄ. ἡμίθεοι Il. 12.23; ἄ. ἥρωες ib. 5.746:—also of men, opp. monsters, Od. 21.303:—of men in societies and cities, οὔτε παρʼ ἀνδράσιν οὔτʼ ἐν ναυσὶ κοίλαις Pi. O. 6.10; and so prob., ἄλλοτε μέν τʼ ἐπὶ Κύνθου ἐβήσαο . ., ἄλλοτε δʼ ἂν νήσους τε καὶ ἀνέρας . . h.Ap. 142.

data.quote: οὔτε παρʼ ἀνδράσιν οὔτʼ ἐν ναυσὶ κοίλαις
ἄλλοτε μέν τʼ ἐπὶ Κύνθου ἐβήσαο . ., ἄλλοτε δʼ ἂν νήσους τε καὶ ἀνέρας . .

children.label: III
children.definition: man, opp. youth, unless the context determines the meaning, as in οὔ πως ἔστι νεωτέρῳ ἀνδρὶ μάχεσθαι ἄνδρα γέροντα Od. 18.53; but ἀ. alone always means a man in the prime of life, esp. warrior, ἀ. ἕλεν ἄνδρα Il. 15.328; so ἀ. ἀντʼ ἀνδρὸς ἐλύθησαν Th. 2.103; the several ages are given as παῖς, μειράκιον, ἀ., πρεσβύτης X. Smp. 4.17; εἰς ἄνδρας ἐγγράφεσθαι, συντελεῖν, D. 19.230, Isoc. 12.212; εἰς ἄνδρας ἀναβῆναι BMus.Inscr. 898; in Inscrr. relating to contests, opp. παῖδες, IG 2(2).1138.10, etc.

data.quote: οὔ πως ἔστι νεωτέρῳ ἀνδρὶ μάχεσθαι ἄνδρα γέροντα

children.label: IV
children.definition: man emphatically, man indeed, ἀνέρες ἄστε, φίλοι Il. 5.529; freq. in Hdt., πολλοὶ μὲν ἄνθρωποι, ὀλίγοι δὲ ἄνδρες 7.210; πρόσθεν οὐκ ἀ. ὅδʼ ἦν; S. Aj. 77; ἄνδρα γίγνεσθαί σε χρή E. El. 693; ἀ. γεγένησαι διʼ ἐμέ Ar. Eq. 1255; ὃ μαθὼν ἀ. ἔσει Id. Nu. 823; ἄνδρας ἡγοῦνται μόνους τοὺς πλεῖστα δυναμένους καταφαγεῖν Id. Ach. 77; εἰ ἄνδρες εἶεν οἱ στρατηγοί Th. 4.27; οὐκέτι ἀ. ἀλλὰ σκευοφόρος X. Cyr. 4.2.25; τὸν Λυκομήδην . . μόνον ἄνδρα ἡγοῦντο Id. HG 7.1.24; οὐκ ἐν ἀνδράσι not like a man, E. Alc. 723, cf. 732; ἀνδρὸς τὰ προσπίπτοντα γενναίως φέρειν ʼtis the part of a man . ., Men. 771, etc.

data.quote: πολλοὶ μὲν ἄνθρωποι, ὀλίγοι δὲ ἄνδρες
ἄνδρας ἡγοῦνται μόνους τοὺς πλεῖστα δυναμένους καταφαγεῖν

children.label: V
children.definition: husband, Il. 19.291, Od. 24.196, Hdt. 1.146, etc.; εἰς ἀνδρὸς ὥραν ἡκούσης τῆς κόρης Pl. Criti. 113d; so ἐξοικιεῖν εἰς ἀνδρὸς [οἶκον] θυγατέρα Luc. Lex. 11:—also of a paramour, opp. πόσις, S. Tr. 551, cf. E. Hipp. 491, Theoc. 15.131; ἀ. ἁπασῶν τῶν γυναικῶν ἐστι νῦν Pherecr. 155; αἰγῶν ἄνερ Theoc. 8.49.

data.quote: εἰς ἀνδρὸς ὥραν ἡκούσης τῆς κόρης
ἀ. ἁπασῶν τῶν γυναικῶν ἐστι νῦν

children.definition: ἰητρὸς ἀ. Il. 11.514; ἀ. μάντις, ἀ. στρατηγός, Hdt. 6.83, 92 (dub.); ἀ. νομεύς S. OT 1118; ἄνδρες λοχῖται, λῃσταί, ἀσπιστῆρες, ib. 751, 842, Aj. 565; esp. in disparagement, κλῶπες ἄ. E. Rh. 645; ἀ. δημότης S. Ant. 690; with names of nations, as Φοίνικες ἄ. Hdt. 4.42; ἀ. Θρῇξ E. Hec. 19, al.; esp. in addresses, ἄ. ἔφοροι Hdt. 9.9; ἄ. πολῖται S. OT 513; ἄ. δικασταί D. 21.1, etc.; ὦ ἄνδρες gentlemen of the jury, Antipho 1.1, Lys. 1.1, etc.; ὦ ἄ. Ἀθηναῖοι Id. 6.8, etc.: hence in Comedy, ἄ. ἰχθύες Archipp. 29; ἄ. θεοί Luc. JTr. 15; ὦ ἄ. κύνες Ath. 4.160b.

ὁ ἀνήρ, by crasis Att. ἁνήρ, Ion. ὡνήρ, is freq. used emphatically for αὐτός, ἐκεῖνος Ar. V. 269, prob. in Pl. Sph. 216b, etc.: sts. so in oblique cases without the Art., S. Tr. 55, 109, 293, etc.; but not in Prose.
ἀ. ὅδε, ὅδʼ ἀ., in Trag., = ἐγώ, S. Aj. 78, E. Alc. 690, etc.
πᾶς ἀ. every man, every one, freq. in Pl. Lg. 736c, al., cf. E. Or. 1523.
a man, any man, εἶτʼ ἄνδρα τῶν αὑτοῦ τι χρὴ προϊέναι; Ar. Nu. 1214; οὐ πρέπει νοῦν ἔχοντι ἀνδρί Pl. Phd. 114d, etc.; οὐ παντὸς ἀνδρὸς . . ἐσθʼ ὁ πλοῦς ʼtis not every one that can go, Nicol.Com. 1.26.

data.quote: εἶτʼ ἄνδρα τῶν αὑτοῦ τι χρὴ προϊέναι;

children.definition: ὦ δαιμόνιʼ ἀνδρῶν Eup. 316; and often with a Sup., ὦ φίλτατʼ ἀνδρῶν Phryn.Com. 80, etc.
κατʼ ἄνδρα viritim, Isoc. 12.180, POxy. 1047 iii 11, BGU 145.5, etc.; so τοὺς κατʼ ἄνδρα individuals, opp. κοινῇ τὴν πόλιν, D.Chr. 32.6.

LXX, ἀνήρ = ἕκαστος, δότε μοι ἀνὴρ ἐνώτιον Jd. 8.24; ἀ. τῷ ἀδελφῷ αὐτοῦ προσκολληθήσεται ‘each to his fellow’, of leviathanʼs scales, Jb. 41.8; also ἀ. εἷς 4 Ki. 6.2; with negs., ἀ. μὴ ἐπισκεπήτω ib. 10.19; ἀνὴρ ἀνήρ any one, Le. 15.2.
ἄνδρας γράφειν· τὸ ἐν διδασκάλου τὰ παιδία ὀνόματα γράφειν, Hsch.

children.label: VII
children.definition: male animal, Arist. HA 637b15.
restless, Corn. ND 26, S.E. M. 3.5. Adv. -τως 10.223.
rings through which cables were passed, Hsch.
not covered, A.R. 2.1171.
GDI 5653 B ( Chios, v B. C.).
Hsch. ἀνήριστα· ἀνέριστα, ἄπλαστα, Id.
Ph.Tars. ap. Gal. 13.267; but ἀνηρόν· ἄβλαπτον, EM 108.22.
unploughed, γύαι A. Pr. 708; without tillage, ἀνήροτα πάντα φύονται Od. 9.109: neut. pl. as Adv., λειμῶνες ἀνήροτα πορφύρουσι Opp. C. 1.462: metaph., γυνὴ ἀ. Luc. Lex. 19.

definition: ἀνηρτημένως, Adv. pf. part. Pass. of ἀναρτάω,

children.definition: disconnectedly, incoherently, Herm. in Phdr. p.177A.
sending up gifts, epith. of Earth, Ath.Mitt. 37.288 (ii A. D.), cf. Sch. Ar. Av. 971; of Demeter, S. Fr. 826, Alciphr. 1.3, Paus. 1.31.4, Plu. QConv. 2.745a; ἑστία ἀ., of Rome, ib. Fort.Rom. 317a.
unconquered, Theoc. 6.46.
A. Fr. 258A, Cratin. 45.
unspun, σίππιον POxy. 1288.34.
inquietus, Gloss.

definition: ἀνήτινος, η, ον, Dor. for ἀνήθ-: ἄνητον or ἄννητον, v. ἄνηθον.

children.definition: that is no fire, i.e. discord, E. Or. 621.
raise a shout, Sch. E. Or. 1335.

choose one person or thing instead of another, τὸ δʼ εὐσεβὲς τῆς δυσσεβείας ἀνθελοῦ E. Cyc. 311; ἄλλους ἀ. ἀντὶ τούτων CIG 2715.11 ( Stratonicea); στρατηγοὺς ἔπαυσαν . . καὶ ἄλλους ἀνθείλοντο Th. 6.103, cf. X. HG 6.2.13, Pl. Lg. 765d; τὰν εὔδοξον ἀ. φήμαν prefer, choose rather, E. Hipp. 773 (lyr.).

data.quote: τὸ δʼ εὐσεβὲς τῆς δυσσεβείας ἀνθελοῦ

children.label: II
children.definition: dispute, lay claim to, οὐδεὶς στέφανον ἀνθαιρήσεται Id. Hec. 660.
choice of one to succeed another, CIG 2715.12.
belonging to the opposite ‘condition’, Jul.Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).183.21, cf. 192.36.
to be captured in turn, i.e. after one has captured others, οὐ τἂν ἑλόντες αὖθις ἀνθαλοῖεν ἄν A. Ag. 340; to be convicted in turn, ἀντικατηγορήθη καὶ ἀνθεάλω D.C. 36.40.

data.quote: οὐ τἂν ἑλόντες αὖθις ἀνθαλοῖεν ἄν

children.definition: err in retaliation, Agath. 4.4.
vie one with another, be rivals, Pl. Lg. 731a; race, of triremes, X. HG 6.2.28:— Act., part. ἀνθαμιλλεῦντες Hp. Ep. 17.
vying with, rivalling, E. Ion 606.
lay hold of in return, οἱ Πέρσαι . . ἅπτοντο αὐτοῦ· . . οἱ δὲ ἀντάπτοντο Hdt. 3.137, cf. E. Hec. 275: but mostly,

data.quote: οἱ Πέρσαι . . ἅπτοντο αὐτοῦ· . . οἱ δὲ ἀντάπτοντο

children.label: II
children.definition: lay hold of, grapple with, engage in, c. gen., ἀ. τοῦ πολέμου Hdt. 7.138; ἀ. τῶν πραγμάτων Th. 8.97; ἀ. τῆς λογιστικῆς Pl. R. 525c: generally, reach, attain, τερμόνων E. Med. 1182 (dub.).

lay hold of, seize, attack, esp. of pain, grief, etc., πλευμόνων S. Tr. 778, cf. Ar. Ra. 474; φρενῶν, καρδίας, E. Med. 55, 1360; περὶ τῆς μισθοφορᾶς . . μαλακωτέρως ἀνθήπτετο (sc. Τισσαφέρνους) attacked him, Th. 8.50 (unless abs., ‘was less firm in his counter-grip’).
pimple, eruption, = ἐρύθημα, Hsch.
fit one thing to another, χειρὶ χεῖρα Sch. Pi. P. 4.65.
a thing seized by way of reprisal or pledge, Eust. 877.37.
Paus. 2.22.1, EM 108.47; at Miletus, in dat., Ἥρῃ Ἀνθέη Milet. 3 No.31(a).5 (vi B. C.); of the Ὧραι, Hsch.; also of Aphrodite at Cnossus, Id.
flower, blossom, dub. in Ar. Ach. 869 ( Boeot.).
one must cleave to, τούτου ἀ. τοῖς ἐπιμεληταῖς Pl. R. 424b; ἀ. τῆς μέσης ἕξεως Arist. EN 1126b9: so in pl., ἀνθεκτέα ἐστὶ τῆς θαλάσσης Th. 1.93.
clinging to, attached to, τινός Arr. Epict. 4.11.3.
preferred, Poet. de herb. 194.
counter-winding, Placit. 3.15.5 (pl.) ( ἀντ- codd.).
the interior curvature of the ear, the exterior being ἕλιξ, Ruf. Onom. 44.

definition: ἀνθέλκω, aor. inf. -ελκύσαι Herm. in Phdr. p.170A.:—

children.definition: draw or pull against, Th. 4.14; ἀ. ἀλλήλαις pull against one another, Pl. Lg. 644e; ἀ. τὴν ψυχήν draw it in a contrary direction, Id. R. 439b; φιλανθρώπως τινὰς ἀ. D.S. 30.8: metaph., of resistance of facts to suggested inference, εἰς τοὐναντίον μηδενὸς -κοντος Phld. Sign. 17, cf. 18; ἀ. τινὰ πρὸς αὑτὰς ἑκάστη Luc. Demon. 63:— Pass., Pl. Ax. 372a, D.H. 3.30.

children.label: II
children.definition: dance, in Ath. 14.629e, unless this be neut. pl. of ἄνθεμον.

definition: ἀνθεμίζομαι, in A. Supp. 73 γοεδνὰ ἀνθεμίζεσθαι, i.e. (says the Sch.) τὸ ἄνθος τῶν γόων ἀποδρέπεσθαι; cf. ἀπανθίζω.

children.definition: Thphr. HP 1.13.3, al., cf. AP 4.1.36 ( Mel.), PMag.Leid.V. 13.9.
honeysuckle pattern on Ionic columns, IG 1.322; so ἀ. ἐστιγμένοι tattooed with a similar pattern, of the Mossynoeci, X. An. 5.4.32: pl., artificial flowers, IG 11.161 B50 ( Delos, iii B.C.).
the purest quality, LXX Ec. 12.6.
camomile, Nic. Fr. 74.37; ἀ. λευκή Matricaria Chamomilla, wild c., ἀ. μελινη Anthemis tinctoria, dyerʼs c., ibid.; ἀ. πορφυρᾶ A. rosea. ibid., Dsc. 3.137.

children.label: b
children.definition: Dsc. 3.136; = ἀργεμώνη, Id. 2.177; = ἀμάρακον, Id. 3.138:—also ἀνθεμίσιον, τό, Alex.Trall. 9.1.
Orph. H. 43.4.

definition: ἀνθεμόεις, εσσα, εν, also εις as fem., Il. 2.695, Hes. Fr. 16:—

children.definition: flowery, of places, ἐν λειμῶνι Σκαμανδρίῳ ἀνθεμόεντι Il. 2.467, cf. 695, B. 12.88; ἐπʼ ἀνθεμόεντι Ἕβρῳ on the flowery banks of Hebrus, 15.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: adorned with flowers, λέβητʼ ἄπυρον . . ἀ. Il. 23.885; ἐν ἀ. λέβητι Od. 3.440; κρητῆρα πανάργυρον ἀ. 24.275; embroidered, κύπασσις AP 6.272 ( Pers.). ( ἀνθεμεῦντας ps.- Ion. form in Anacr. 62.)

Sapph. 85, Semon. 7.66, Pi. N. 7.79, Cratin. 98, Ar. Ach. 992, Tab.Heracl. 1.96; ἄνθεμα χρυσοῦ golden flowers, Pi. O. 2.72; ἄνθεμʼ ὀρειχάλκου h.Hom. 6.9; ἄνθεμα κοτταβείων IG 11.164B25 ( Delos, iii B.C.).
plant, ἄ. ἀφύλλανθες Matricaria Chamomilla var. eradiata, and ἄ. φυλλῶδες Anthemis chia, Thphr. HP 7.8.3.
cake, Poll. 6.76, Hsch.
flowing from flowers, ἀ. γάνος μελίσσης, i.e. honey, E. IT 634.
strewn with flowers, E. ap. Phot. p.138R.
working in flowers, ἡ ἀ., i.e. the bee, A. Pers. 612.

definition: Ἀνθεμουσία τάγμα τι παρὰ Μακεδόσιν ἐξ Ἀνθεμοῦντος πόλεως Μακεδονίας, Hsch.

children.definition: flowery, blooming, μελίλωτος Sapph. 96.14 L.-P.; Νεῖλος B. 18.39; ἔαρ A. Pr. 455; τμῶλος E. Ba. 462; λειμών Ar. Ra. 450.
adorned with flowers or with flower-patterns, καλυπτήρ IG 2.807b107.
clinging to, ἀλλήλων Pl. Ep. 323b (pl.).

definition: ἄνθεο, Ep. aor. 2 imper. Med. of ἀνατίθημι.

children.definition: chin, δεξιτερῇ δʼ ἄρʼ ὑπʼ ἀνθερεῶνος ἑλοῦσα, in token of supplication, Il. 1.501; παρὰ νείατον ἀνθερεῶνα, i.e. just under the chin, 5.293, cf. Hp. Oss. 18, Nic. Th. 444.
neck, throat, Euph. 92.1 (pl.): sg., AP 9.129 ( Nestor), Q.S. 1.110: sg. in both senses, Ruf. Onom. 47, 48.
flowering stem of asphodel, Thphr. HP 7.13.2, cf. Hp. Coac. 491, Hellanic. 67 J., Longus 1.10; and so prob. ἐξ ἀνθερίκων in Hdt. 4.190, which others refer to ἀνθέριξ.
flower-head of asphodel, Dsc. 2.169.
the plant itself, asphodel, Cratin. 325, Eup. 14.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: Arat. 1060.
like asphodel, καυλός Thphr. HP 9.10.1.
beard of an ear of corn, the ear itself, Il. 20.227, Hes. Fr. 117, AP 12.121 ( Rhian.).

children.label: II
children.definition: stalk of asphodel, v.l. in Theoc. 1.52.

definition: ἄνθεσαν, Ep. 3 pl. aor. 2 Act. of ἀνατίθημι.

children.definition: creating flowers, Orph. Fr. 197.
fluttering round flowers, μέλεα Antiph. 209.
variegated, πέρκη Matro Conv. 51.

Feast of Flowers, i.e. three days’ festival of Dionysus at Athens, in the month Anthesterion, Apollod. Fr. 28; also in Ionic cities, SIG 38.32 ( Teos), CIG 3655 ( Cyzicus). (Deriv. from ἀνα-θέσσασθαι is dub.; from ἀνθεῖν acc. to Ister 28.)

definition: Ἀνθεστηριάδας τὰς ἐχούσας ὥραν γάμου(Rhod.), Hsch.

children.definition: Anthesterion, eighth of the Attic year, answering to the end of February and the beginning of March, in which the Anthesteria were celebrated, Th. 2.15, etc.; also in Ionic cities, as Tenos, IG 12(5).872.48.
entertain in return or mutually, Plu. Ant. 27, cf. 32 ( Pass.), Luc. Am. 9.
gathering flowers, Poll. 1.37.
bearing flowers, flowery, μῖλαξ E. Ba. 703; λείμακες ἀνθεσφόροι Id. IA 1544.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀνθεσφόροι, αἱ, women celebrating the Anthesphoria, Poll. 4.78.

definition: ἄνθετο, Ep. 3 sg. aor. 2 Med. of ἀνατίθημι.

children.definition: blossom, bloom, of the youthful beard, πρὶν . . ὑπὸ κροτάφοισιν ἰούλους ἀνθῆσαι Od. 11.320 (the only place in Hom.), cf. Orph. L. 255; of persons, τυτθὸν δʼ ἀνθήσαντας ὑπὸ κροτάφοισιν ἴουλον with the young down just showing, IG 5(1).1355 ( Geraneia), cf. APl. 16.381.

Hes. Op. 582, Alc. 39; στάχυς S. Fr. 395; flourish, ἀ. κυπάρισσοι Theoc. 27.46: c. dat., ἄνθεσιν h.Ap. 139; ῥόδοις Pi. I. 4(3).18: metaph., ἀνθοῦν πέλαγος Αἰγαῖον νεκροῖς A. Ag. 659; ἀφρὸς ἤνσει ( Lacon.) dub.l. in Ar. Lys. 1257.
bloom, be brilliant, shine with colour, etc., ἤνθει φοινικίσι . . ἡ στρατιά X. Cyr. 6.4.1; of linen garments, Plu. Isid. 2.352d.

to be in bloom, blooming, Ἥβας καρπὸν ἀνθήσαντα Pi. P. 9.110; ἀνθοῦσαν ἀκμὴν ἔχων Isoc. 5.10; ἐν ὥρᾳ ἀνθεῖν to be in the bloom of youth, Pl. R. 475a; τὰ σὰ λήγει ὥρας, σὺ δʼ ἄρχῃ ἀνθεῖν Id. Alc. 1.131e, cf. ib.c.

data.quote: τὰ σὰ λήγει ὥρας, σὺ δʼ ἄρχῃ ἀνθεῖν

children.definition: flourish in wealth and prosperity, λαοί Hes. Op. 227; ἀνθεύσης Ἐρετρίης Hdt. 6.127, cf. Th. 1.19, etc.; ὄλβος σμικρὸν ἀνθήσας χρόνον E. El. 944; ἀνθοῦσα ἐφʼ ὥρᾳ πολιτεία Plu. Per. 16; ἀνθούσης τῆς νέας Ἀκαδημίας Id. Luc. 42; τὸ ἀνθοῦν τῆς δυνάμεως the flower of the force, Id. Cor. 39: c. dat., ἀ. τῆς Ἀσίας ἀνδράσι flourish, abound in men, Hdt. 4.1.

children.label: b
children.definition: flourish, be popular, οὕτως ἤνθησεν ἐκεῖνος Ar. Eq. 530, cf. Nu. 897, 962; πραπίδεσσι, δόξῃ ἀ., Pi. O. 11(10).10, Plu. Dem. 5; Ἕκτορος ἤνθει δόρυ E. Hec. 1210; σφόδρα γε ἤνθησεν ἐπὶ ταῖς ἐλπίσιν D. 2.10; ἀ. πρὸς δόξαν, πρὸς χάριν, Plu. Sert. 18, Phoc. 3.

data.quote: σφόδρα γε ἤνθησεν ἐπὶ ταῖς ἐλπίσιν

children.definition: to be at the height or pitch, ἀνθεῖ πάθος τινί A. Ch. 1009 (lyr.); of a disease, ἤνθηκεν S. Tr. 1089, cf. Hp. Epid. 1.25; ὕβρις ἐν νέοις ἀνθεῖ S. Fr. 786; σκωμμάτων ἀνθούντων when they were in full swing, Plu. Ant. 32.
swarm with, φθειρῶν ἤνθησεν Paus. 9.33.6.
flower-bed or garden, OGI 365 ( Amasia):—also ἀνθών, Gloss.
full bloom of a flower or plant, ἀκμὴν ἔχει τῆς ἄνθης Pl. Phdr. 230b, cf. Porph. ap. Eus. PE 3.10: a special Att. form, Moer. 4, Thom.Mag. p.10 R.
blossom or bloom, Nic. Th. 625, Ael. NA 12.4.
the flowery one, i.e. the bee, Damocr. ap. Gal. 14.91, Ael. NA 15.1, EM 108.43.

children.label: II
children.definition: eastern thorn, Crataegus orientalis, Thphr. HP 3.12.5:—hence ἀνθηδονοειδής, ές, as epith. of Crataegus monogyna, hawthorn, ibid.
bright-coloured, βασιλίσκος Marc.Sid. 26; σάλπη Id. 30; κίστος Ruf. ap. Gal. 12.425.
flower-merchant, PLond. 2.387.21 (vi/vii A.D.).
the silky flower-tufts of the reed, Thphr. HP 4.10.4, Dsc. 1.85, cj. for ἀνθίνη in Phan.Hist. 25:— ἀνθήλη· πώγων, Hsch. (cf. ἀνθήλη πυρός Id.).

definition: ἀνθήλιον, τό, f.l. for ἀνθύλλιον, Dsc. 3.156, 4.121; = κανθήλιον, Charax 21:— ἀνθήλια· περιδέρματα, Hsch. ( -ηλά· περίδερμα cod.).

children.definition: Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: Nic. Al. 406.

definition: ἄνθημα (B), ατος, τό, poet. for ἀνάθημα,

children.definition: offering, IG 12(5).911.21 ( Tenos).
to-day, prob. in S. Fr. 168; cf. ἀντί A. II, ἀνταλλές.
Nic. Al. 610.
write in a florid style, Eust. 991.8:— Pass., to be embellished, Cic. Att. 2.6.1.
brocaded with flowers, flowered, Ph. 1.666.

flowery, blooming, ἔαρ Chaerem. 9; λειμών, δάπεδον, Ar. Av. 1093, Ra. 352; χώρα Str. 17.3.12 ( Comp.); πρόσοψις, διάθεσις, D.S. 5.3, 19; τὰ ἀ. flowery meads, Plu. Amat. 2.770b; but also, flowering plants, ib. 765d.

children.label: II
children.definition: fresh, young, χλόη E. Cyc. 541; of music, etc., fresh, new, X. Cyr. 1.6.38; of persons, Plu. Pomp. 69; ἱλαρὸς καὶ ἀ. Adul. 2.50b; cf. ἄνθος II.1 fin.
τᾶς μανίας ἀνθηρὸν μένος rage bursting (as it were) into flower, i.e. exuberant, S. Ant. 960.
bright-coloured, brilliant, τοῦ χαλκοῦ τὸ ἀ. Plu. Pyth. 2.395b; of colours, τὸ ἀ. τῶν χρωμάτων Luc. Nigr. 13. cf. Plu. Profect. 2.79d, etc.

brilliant, splendid, δειπνάριον Diph. 64; ἐδωδή Ph. 1.679 ( Comp.) (s.v.l.); βίος Max.Tyr. 21.1; θεωρία Iamb. in Nic. p.35P.; of personal appearance, dress, etc., ἀνθηρὸς εἱμάτων στολῇ E. IA 73. Adv. -ῶς Sch. Opp. H. 1.459.

flowery, florid, ἀ. genus dicendi Quint. Inst. 12.10.58, cf. Plu. QConv. 2.648b; of music, ἀ. καὶ μαλακὴ ἁρμονία (metaph. of policy), Id. Per. 15; ἂν ἀ. ᾖ τὸ πρᾶγμα, ἔστω καὶ ἡ λέξις τοιαύτη Hermog. Prog. 10. Adv. " ἀνθηρῶς", an exclamation of applause, Plu. Aud. 2.46a: Comp. ἀνθηρότερον, λέγειν Isoc. 13.18.

data.quote: ἂν ἀ. ᾖ τὸ πρᾶγμα, ἔστω καὶ ἡ λέξις τοιαύτη

children.label: III
children.definition: ἀνθηρός, ὁ, = ἅλιμον, Ps.- Dsc. 1.91.
ἀνθηρά, ἡ, name of a lip-salve, Plin. HN 24.69, Gal. 13.839; also of a plaster, Cels. 6.11, Sor. ap. Gal. 12.957.
brilliancy, Sch. Pi. O. 9.72.
flowering, Thphr. CP 4.10.1, Plu. QConv. 2.647f.
give way or yield in turn, τινί Th. 4.19, D.C. 49.44.
to be quiet in turn, App. BC 2.93.
flowering plants, Thphr. HP 1.14.3.
CIG 2821,2822 ( Aphrodisias); but ἀρχιέρεια ἀ, Rev.Ét.Gr. 19p.137.
sea-fish, Labrus or Serranus anthias (Adams), Anan. 5.1, Epich. 58, Diph. 64; = αὐλωπίας, Arist. HA 570b19.
consecrate in return, Epicur. Fr. 141.

strew or deck with flowers, E. Ion 890; κεφαλὴν ῥόδοις Philostr. Im. 1.15 (but σκευὴ ἠνθισμένη adorned, embroidered with flowers, ibid.): metaph., ἀ. τὴν λέξιν D.H. Isoc. 13:— Med., gather, cull flowers, App. BC 4.105.

colour, dye, stain, [ πορφύρα] ἀ. τὴν χεῖρα Arist. HA 547a18:— Pass., ἠνθισμένοι φαρμάκοισι Hdt. 1.98; οὐ γάρ σε μὴ . . γνῶσʼ . . ὧδʼ ἠνθισμένον thus disguised or with silvered hair, S. El. 43; κρέα πυρὸς ἀκμαῖς ἠνθισμένα meat browned at the fire, Epicr. 6; οἶνος ἠνθισμένος wine flavoured with flowers, Gal. 19.81.
ἀνθίζουσα, ἡ, a plaster, Id. 13.856.
flowering, τὰ ἀ., opp. τὰ φρυγανικά, Thphr. HP 6.62.
= sq., μελίσσης ἄ. εἶδαρ Orph. L. 735.

of or like flowers, blooming, fresh, like ἀνθηρός: in Od. 9.84 the esculent lotus is called ἄνθινον εἶδαρ, where prob. vegetable as opp. to animal food is all that is meant; ἄ. κυκεών a drink flavoured with flowers, Hp. Int. 12; ἄ. ἔλαιον oil of lilies, Id. Mul. 1.35; ἄ. μέλι Arist. Mir. 831b18; ἄ. οἶνος Gal. 19.81; τριμμάτιον Sotad.Com. 1.17; στέφανος SIG 1017.12 ( Sinope); εὐωδία Plu. QConv. 2.645e.

children.label: II
children.definition: flowered, bright-coloured, of womenʼs dress, ἐσθῆτες, στολή, Str. 3.3.7, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.304d; τὰ ἄνθινα (sc. ἱμάτια) gay-coloured dresses worn by the ἑταῖραι at Athens, Phylarch. 45; forbidden at religious festivals, IG 11.1300 ( Delos), ib. 5(2).514.6 ( Lycosura, ii B.C.); also of dresses worn at the Anthesteria by the Satyrs: hence τὴν φιλοσοφίαν ἄνθινα ἐνέδυσεν he clothed philosophy in motley, of Bion, who delivered his precepts in sarcastic verses, like those used in the satyric drama, Eratosth. ap. D.L. 4.52, cf. Thphr. ap. Demetr.Lac. Herc. 1055.15, Str. 1.2.2. (On the accent v. Hdn.Gr. 1.182.)
spring, Orph. Fr. 33.
deputy-master of the horse, Lyd. Mag. 1.38.
sham fight of horse, X. Eq.Mag. 1.20, IG 2.1291, cf. 1305b.
ride against, ἀλλήλοις, of cavalry, X. Eq. 8.12.
lustre, of dyes, PHolm. 18.25.

definition: ἀνθιστάω, later form of ἀνθίστημι, dub. in Hermog. Stat. 2:—also ἀνθ-ιστάνω, PPetr. 2p.120.

children.definition: set against, Th. 4.115; esp. in battle, πελταστικὴν τῆ τοῦ παγκρατίου μάχῃ Pl. Lg. 834a; ἀ. τροπαῖον set up a trophy in opposition, Th. 1.54, 105; weigh against, Ar. Ra. 1389; ἀ. τινὸς τὴν ὁλκήν outweigh him, LXX Si. 8.2.
match with, compare, ἀντιστῆσαι καὶ παραβαλεῖν Plu. Thes. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: Hom. uses only Pass., with intr. aor. 2 ἀντέστην. aor. 1 Pass. ἀντεστάθην Hdt. 5.72: pf. ἀνθέστηκα Ep.Rom. 9.19; Att. contr. part. ἀνθεστώς Th. 6.70: fut. ἀντιστήσομαι Hdt. 8.75, S. OC 645:— stand against, esp. in battle, withstand, Ἥρῃ δʼ ἀντέστη . . Ἄρτεμις Il. 20.70, cf. 72, Hdt. 6.117 al.; τοὺς ἀνθισταμένους τοῖς ὑμετέροις βουλήμασι D. 18.49; πρὸς τὴν ἀνάγκην οὐδʼ Ἄρης ἀ. S. Fr. 256, cf. Th. 1.93, X. Smp. 5.1: rarely c. gen., δέος . . σοὶ φρενῶν ἀνθίσταται A. Pers. 703 ( ἀνθάπτεται Wakef.), cf. Q.S. 1.520.

data.quote: πρὸς τὴν ἀνάγκην οὐδʼ Ἄρης ἀ.

children.definition: turn out unfavourably to one, ἀντιστάντος αὐτῷ τοῦ πράγματος Th. 5.4, cf. 38; ἄν τὰ παρʼ ὑμῶν τῶν ἀκουόντων ἀντιστῇ D. 19.340.

data.quote: ἄν τὰ παρʼ ὑμῶν τῶν ἀκουόντων ἀντιστῇ

children.definition: make a stand, ἀλλʼ ἔτʼ ἄρʼ ἀνθίσταντο Il. 16.305; resist, fight on, Hdt. 5.72, etc.; ὑπέρ τινος S. Aj. 1231, Ant. 518.
bright-coloured, στρωμνή Antyll. ap. Orib. 9.14.7, cf. Ph. 2.274; ἐσθής S.E. P. 1.148; πέδιλα Luc. Am. 41; γῆ IG 7.1802.
dyeing in bright colours, Plu. Fr. 16p.113B.
dyer in bright colours, Pl. 2.830e, Man. 2.326.
bestrew with flowers, χαίτην AP 5.146 ( Mel.); as a mark of honour, ὥσπερ ἀθλητὴν ἀ. Plu. Caes. 30:— Pass., Id. Pomp. 57.

children.label: II
children.definition: put forth flowers, Gp. 10.2.10.
putting forth of flowers, Gp. 10:59.3.
garlanded with flowers, θρίξ AP 9.270 ( Marc.Arg.), but codd. have ἀνθοβόλον, i.e. shedding flowers.
nourishing, growing flowers, or perh. feeding on flowers, S. Fr. 31.
paint in bright colours, Ph. 1.33.
living on flowers, μέλισσα AP 5.162 ( Mel.).
holding flowers, τάλαρος Mosch. 2.34.
crowned with flowers, Opp. C. 4.235.
produce flowers, of the earth, βοτάνας ἀ. AP 7.321.
decked with flowers, flowery, λειμῶνες AP 10.6 ( Satyr.).
parti-coloured, οἰωνοί Opp. C. 2.190.
govern flowers, Luc. Pseudol. 24.
worked with flowers, πῆναι E. Hec. 471 (lyr.).

pulling in the contrary direction, retraction, Aret. CA 1.4; revulsion in venesection, Antyll. ap. Orib. 7.11.1; means of drawing back, D.C. 35.5; counterpoise, τοῦ βλάπτοντος ἀ. Plu. Aud.poet. 2.20c; resistance, countercheck, ἀνθολκαὶ καὶ διατριβαί Id. Luc. 11.
Iamb. Protr. 21.κβ.
gather flowers, Plu. Aet. phys. 2.917f: c.acc., Hp. Ep. 16, Porph. Abst. 2.6:— Med., of bees, gather honey from flowers, Arist. HA 628b32:— Pass., Gp. 11.26.2.
flower-gathering, Luc. Pisc. 6.
books on floristics, Plin. HN 21.13.
collection of extracts, ἐπιγραμμάτων Suid. s.v. Διογενειανός, cf. eund. s. vv. Ὠρίων, Ὦρος.
flower-gathering, AP 12.249 ( Strat.): c. gen., culling the flower of, κάλλευς ib. 95 ( Mel.).
associate, deal with one another, Hp. Ep. 17 (but f.l. for ἀνθαμιλλεῦντες).
compare, τὸν νόμον τῇ φύσει Philostr. Dial. 2:— Pass., to be compared in turn, πρὸς ἄλληλα Iamb. in Nic. p.12P.
like, ὕδωρ μέλιτος Ps.-Callisth. 2.42.
make a mutual agreement or covenant, πρός τινα D. 33.8 (s.v.l.), Plb. 5.105.2; ὑπέρ τινος 15.19.9; τινί PTeb. 21.6 (ii B.C.); περί τινος ib. 410.14 (16 A.D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: confess freely and openly, τὰς ἀρετάς τινος D.S. 1.70; ἁμαρτίας J. AJ 8.10.3; τὸν τοῦ βασιλέως θάνατον Plb. 15.25.4: abs., 30.8.7.
admit, signify, πρός τινα μηδὲν ἑωρακέναι 29.17.1; ὡς . . Plu. Brut. 16.
assent, agree, τοῖς εἰρημένοις Plb. 28.4.4.
return thanks to God, LXX Ps. 78(79).13. Ev.Luc. 2.38; χάριν ἀ. return thanks, Plu. Aem. 11:— Act., -λογέω admit a claim, is late, PGrenf. 2.71i i14 (iii A.D.).
mutual agreement, Plb. 31.24.12, 36.4.4.
confession, admission, testimony, S.E. M. 7.184, 8.453.
feed on flowers, A. Supp. 44.
browsing on flowers, A. Supp. 539.
arm against, ἱππεῦσι δʼ ἱππῆς ἦσαν ἀνθωπλισμένοι E. Supp. 666; ἀνθώπλισται πρὸς τὰ πολέμια πλοῖα X. Oec. 8.12:— Med., arm oneself, Id. HG 6.5.7.
counter-arming, hostile armament, Sch. Th. 1.141.
one armed in like manner, Lyc. 64.
plaiting of flowers, Jul.Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).189.9.
one who plaits flowers, Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).209. 9.
flower-seller, Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 8(4).211.
make a counter-definition, in Med., Sch. D. 21.28, PLond. 2.355.4 (i A.D.); define terms by their mutual relations, Elias in Cat. 138.9.
counter-definition, Hermog. Stat. 4, Inv. 3.14, cf. Sch. D. 21.28; alternative definition, Elias in Cat. 205.25.
lie at anchor opposite, τινί Th. 7.19; ἀ. ἀλλήλοις, of two hostile squadrons before fighting, 2.86; ἀ. πρός τινα 7.34.
corresponding boundary-stone, Tab.Heracl. 1.60.

definition: ἄνθος (A), ους, τό, gen. pl. ἀνθέων, freq. used for ἀνθῶν, S. El. 896, Hermipp. 5, 6, Eub. 105, Aristag. 3; but ἀνθῶν Pherecr. 46, Pl. Criti. 115a, X. Cyn. 5.5:—

children.definition: blossom, flower, πέτονται ἐπʼ ἄνθεσιν εἰαρινοῖσιν Il. 2.89; ὑακινθίνῳ ἄνθει ὁμοίας Od. 6.231; βρύει ἄνθεϊ λευκῷ Il. 17.56; τέρενʼ ἄνθεα ποίης Od. 9.449; ἐπʼ ἄνθεσιν ἵζειν Ar. Eq. 403; δένδρα καὶ ἄνθη καὶ καρπούς Pl. Phd. 110d; ἡ κατʼ ἄνθη δίαιτα Id. Smp. 196a; ἄνθεα τεθρίππων the chaplets of flowers which graced them, Pi. O. 2.50, cf. 7.80; [ Δάφνιν] φέρβον μαλακοῖς ἄνθεσσι μέλισσαι, i.e. with honey, Theoc. 7.81.

anything thrown out upon the surface, eruption, προσώπου Hp. Coac. 416; cf. ἐξανθέω. froth or scum, ἄ. οἴνου Gal. 11.628, Gp. 6.3.9,7.15.6; ἄνθη χαλκοῦ, = χάλκανθος, Nic. Th. 257; ἄ. χαλκοῦ, v. χαλκός; ἄ. χρυσοῦ, = ἀδάμας, Poll. 7.99.
embroidered flowers on garments, Hermipp. 5, 6, Pl. R. 557c, Cypr. Fr. 4.

children.label: II
children.definition: bloom, flower of life, ἥβης ἄ. Il. 13.484, Pi. P. 4.158, A. Supp. 663; ἥβης ἄνθεσι Sol. 25; κουρήιον ἄ. h.Cer. 108; ὥρας ἄ. X. Smp. 8.14; παῖς καλὸν ἄ. ἔχων Thgn. 994; χροιᾶς ἀμείψεις ἄ. the bloom of complexion, A. Pr. 23; τὸ τοῦ σώματος ἄ. its youthful bloom, Pl. Smp. 183e; ὅταν [τὰ πρόσωπα] τὸ ἄ. προλίπῃ Id. R. 601b; also, the flower of an army and the like, ἄ. Ἄργους A. Ag. 197; ἄ. Περσίδος αἴας Id. Pers. 59, cf. 252, 925, E. HF 876 (lyr.); ὅ τι ἦν αὐτῶν ἄ. ἀπολώλει Th. 4.133; ἄνθεα ὕμνων νεωτέρων the choice flowers of new songs, Pi. O. 9.48; τὸ σὸν . . ἄ, παντέχνου πυρὸς σέλας thy pride or honour, A. Pr. 7; τὰ ἄνθη flowers or choice passages, elegant extracts, APl. 16.274, Cic. Att. 16.11.1.

data.quote: ὅ τι ἦν αὐτῶν ἄ. ἀπολώλει

children.definition: the bloom, i.e. height of anything, bad as well as good, δηξίθυμον ἔρωτος ἄ. A. Ag. 743; ἀκήλητον μανίας ἄ. S. Tr. 999; ἀ. τοῦ νοῦ Procl. in Alc. p.248C., Dam. Pr. 70; τῆς οὐσίας Procl. in Ti. 1.412D.; τῆς ψυχῆς ib. 472D.

children.label: III
children.definition: brightness, brilliancy, as of gold, Thgn. 452; χαλκήϊον ἄ. Orph. Fr. 174; of dyes, lustre, PHolm. 17.37; freq. of purple, in sg., Pl. R. 429d, Arist. HA 547a7, J. AJ 3.6.1; ἁλὸς ἄνθεα AP 6.206 (Antip. Sid.); of bright colours generally, περιβόλαια παντὸς ἄνθους D.H. 7.72; ἄ. θαλάσσιον seaweed dye, Ps.-Democr.Alch. p.42B.

children.label: IV
children.definition: ἄ. πεδινόν, = ἀνθεμίς, Ps.- Dsc. 3.136.
bird, perh. the yellow wagtail, Arist. HA 592b25, 609b14, Ael. NA 5.48.

redolent of flowers, almost always of wine, οἶνος ἀ. with a fine bouquet, Hp. Steril. 235, Ar. Pl. 807, Ra. 1150, Pherecr. 108.30; also ἀ. (sc. οἶνος) X. HG 6.2.6, Luc. Sat. 22:—in Id. Lex. 2 ἀ. λειμῶνες, as a pedantic phrase:—also ἀνθόσμ-ιος, ον, Sch. Ar. Ra. 1150.
bloom, luxuriant growth, τεκέων AP 5.275 ( Agath.); ὑλαίη ib. 11.365 ( Id.).
Aristonous 1.21.
gather honey from flowers, of bees, Arist. HA 625b19.

children.label: II
children.definition: produce flowers, AP 10.16 ( Theaet.).

children.label: III
children.definition: to be an ἀνθοφόρος II, IG 12(8).553 ( Thasos) ( -ίσασα lapis).
bearing flowers, flowery, ἄλσος Ar. Ra. 445, AP 12.256 ( Mel.); opp. κάρπιμος, Thphr. CP 1.5.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀνθοφόρος, ἡ, flower-bearer, title of a priestess of Demeter and Kore, IG 12(8).526 ( Thasos), cf. 609 (ibid.)
parti-coloured, πτέρυξ, of a parrot, AP 9.562 ( Crin.).

children.label: II
children.definition: producing flowers, βῶλος IG 12(9).954.13 ( Chalcis).
carbonarius, Gloss.
making of charcoal, Thphr. HP 3.8.7.
charcoal-maker, Aesop. 59, Cic. Att. 15.5.1 (cj.), Them. Or. 21.245a, App. BC 4.40:—also ἀνθρᾰκ-ευτής, οῦ, ὁ, And. Fr. 4, Ael. NA 1.8.
which can be carbonized, Arist. Mete. 387b19.
make charcoal, Thphr. HP 9.3.1, cf. Poll. 7.146; τὰ ἀνθρακευόμενα charcoal, Antig. Mir. 136.
burn to a cinder, ἀ. τινὰ πυρί Ar. Lys. 340.
belonging to charcoal, Alex. 208, SIG 975.40 ( Delos, iii B.C.).

definition: ἀνθρακιά, ᾶς, Ep. ἀνθρᾰκ-ιή, ῆς, ἡ,

children.definition: burning charcoal, hot embers, ἀνθρακιὴν στορέσαι Il. 9.213; ὑποθεῖναι Hp. Nat.Mul. 61; ἀνθρακιᾶς ἄπο a broil hot from the embers, E. Cyc. 358, cf. AP 6.105 ( Apollonid.); ἐπʼ ἀνθρακιᾶς ὀπτῆσαι Cratin. 143; σου τῆς ἀνθρακιᾶς ἀπολαύει warms himself at your fire, Ar. Eq. 780: metaph. of lovers, τιθέναι τινὰ ὑπὸ ἀνθρακιῆ or ἀνθρακιήν AP 12.17, 166 ( Asclep.); Κύπριδος ἀ. ib. 5.210 ( Posidipp.).
black sooty ashes, ib. 11.66 ( Antiphil.).
burnt to a cinder, Luc. Icar. 13, cf. DMort. 6[20].4, al.
small fish for frying, Philyll. 13.3.
make charcoal of, roast or toast, Ar. Pax 1136; carbonize, PHolm. 6.4.
of the nature of, or made of, a carbuncle, LXX Es. 1.7.
ἀνθρακίνου βαφή blue dye (woad), PHolm. 18.35.

definition: ἀνθράκιον, τό, Dim. of ἄνθραξ, a stone of which mirrors were made, Thphr. Lap. 33.

children.label: II
children.definition: Dim. of ἄνθραξ II.1, IG 11.161 B82 ( Delos, iii B.C.); of ἄνθραξ II 2, Cass.Fel. 22.

children.label: III
children.definition: brazier, Alex. 134.

definition: ἀνθρακίτης [ῑ], ου, ὁ, name of a

children.definition: gem, Plin. HN 36.148.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀνθρᾰκ-ῖτις, ιδος, a kind of coal, ib. 37.99.
betony, Gloss.
like, or of the colour of, coal, Ph. 1.383.
coal-cellar, Gloss.
Ar. Ach. 326.
to be burnt to cinders or ashes, κεραυνῷ Ζηνὸς ἠνθρακωμένος A. Pr. 374, cf. E. Cyc. 614, Thphr. Lap. 12.

children.label: II
children.definition: form a malignant ulcer (cf. ἀνθράκωσις), Aët. 7.2.
coal-merchant, Philyll. 14.
Hp. Mul. 11, Arist. Sens. 437b17, Diog.Oen. 8.
heap of charcoal, coal-fire, Dsc. Eup. 1.45.
coal-store, Hdn.Gr. 1.30, 2.860.
malignant ulcer, commonly in the eye, Paul.Aeg. 3.22.
carbuncle, Gal. 14.777.

children.label: II
children.definition: carbonization, charring, Dsc. Eup. 1.49.

charcoal, Sotad.Com. 1.12: mostly in pl. ἄνθρακες Ar. Ach. 34, 332, Nu. 97; ἄ. Παρνήθιοι Id. Ach. 348; ὀπτωμέναις κόγχαισιν ἐπί τῶν ἀ. Id. Fr. 68; ἄνθρακας ἡμμένους Th. 4.100, etc.; their vapour produced stupor, Arist. Sens. 444b31: prov., ἄνθρακας κατεσθίειν, of a glutton, Euphro 10.14, cf. Ion Trag. 29.
coal, οἷς καὶ οἱ χαλκεῖς χρῶνται Thphr. Lap. 16, PHolm. 2.33; ἐπὶ ἀνθράκων μαλακῶν on a slow fire, Xenocr. 16.

children.label: II
children.definition: carbuncle, ruby, and garnet (Adams), Arist. Mete. 387b18, LXX Ex. 28.18, Phylarch. 41, etc.
carbuncle, malignant pustule (acc. to some, small-pox), Hp. Epid. 3.7, Gal. 7.719, al.

children.label: III
children.definition: woad, PHolm. 18.34, al.
hornet, D.S. 17.75, Hsch.
Phot. p.140 R.
hornet, wasp, Ar. Nu. 947; in Arist. the name seems to be given to several diff. species, HA 628b32, al.
waspʼs nest, Ar. V. 1080, 1107; Μουσῶν ἀνθρήνιον, of Sophocles, Philostr.Jun. Im. 13 (= Com.Adesp. 22).
honeycombed, ἀ. καὶ πολύπορος Plu. Aet. phys. 2.916e.
like an ἀνθρήνη, Thphr. HP 7.13.3.
chervil, Scandix australis, Sapph. 96.13 L.-P., Cratin. 98.6, Pherecr. 109 ( ἔνθ-), Thphr. HP 7.7.1 ( ἔνθ-):—in Hsch. ἀνθρίσκιον, τό; in Poll. 6.106 ἀνθρίσκος, ὁ.
man-pleaser, LXX Ps. 52(53).6, Ep.Eph. 6.6, Ep.Col. 3.22.
Dim. of ἄνθρωπος, manikin, Eup. 26D., Ar. Pl. 416, Demad. 51 (of Demosthenes), Arr. Epict. 1.3.5.
manʼs skin, like ἀλωπεκῆ, λεοντῆ, etc., Hdt. 5.25 codd., Poll. 2.5.

definition: ἀνθρώπειος, α, ον, Ion. ἀνθρωπήϊος, η, ον, ( ος, ον Luc. Asin. 46):—

children.definition: human, opp. θεῖος, Heraclit. 78; τὰ -ήϊα Democr. 37; ἀνθρωπηΐη φωνή Hdt. 2.55; ἡ ἀ. φύσις Id. 3.65, al.; ἀ. σῶμα Canthar. 3D., ἀ. τι παθεῖν IG 5(1).1208.52 ( Gythium); ἀ. πήματα such as man is subject to, A. Pers. 706; ἀ. ψόγος reproach of men, Id. Ag. 937; τέχνη ἀ. Th. 2.47; ἀνθρωπήϊα πρήγματα human affairs, Hdt. 1.32, cf. Pl. Prm. 134e; τὰ ἀ. A. Fr. 159, Pl. Phd. 89e; ἅπαντα τἀ. S. Aj. 132, Antiph. 240b, etc.; τὸ ἀ. mankind, human nature, πέφυκε τὸ ἀ. ἄρχειν τοῦ εἴκοντος Th. 4.61, cf. 5.105.

data.quote: πέφυκε τὸ ἀ. ἄρχειν τοῦ εἴκοντος

children.definition: human, suited to man, within manʼs powers, ἡ ἀ. εὐδαιμονίη Hdt. 1.5; ἀδύνατον καὶ οὐκ ἀ. not for man to attempt, Pl. Prt. 344c; ὅσα γε τἀ. in all human probability, Id. Cri. 47a; κατὰ τὸ ἀ. (v.l. -πινον) Th. 1.22.
human, opp. mythical, ἡ ἀ. λεγομένη γενεή Hdt. 3.122.
ἀνθρωπείους ἡμέρας· τὰς ἀποφράδας (Rhod.), Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. -ως by human means, in all human probability, Th. 5.103; ἀ. φράζειν to speak as befits a man, Ar. Ra. 1058.—Said to be the correct Attic form by Moer. 26.
act as a human being, as opp. both to gods and beasts, Arist. EN 1178b7; ψυχὴ ἀνθρωπευομένη a human soul, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.41.68.
act like a man, play the man, Archyt. ap. D.L. 3.22; opp. κυνάω, Luc. Demon. 21: -so in Med., Ar. Fr. 37.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., become man, Alex.Aphr. in Top. 137.27, Simp. in Ph. 1138.28:—so in Act., AP 1.105.

human, ἔργα Philol. 11, cf. Pl. Sph. 268d; ἡ ἀ. ἀρετή EN 1102b12, cf. 1178a21, al.: ἀνθρωπικόν [ἐστι], c. inf., it is like a man, suited to manʼs nature, ib. 1163b24, al.: Comp. -κώτεροι, οἱ, the commoner specimens of humanity, Plot. 2.9.9; ἀ. μῦθος a play dealing with human characters, Ar. Fr. 3D.; παρασκευή Phryn. PS p.135B. Adv. -κῶς Luc. Zeux. 4, Plu. Es. carn. 2 2.999b, Porph. Abst. 3.4.

definition: ἀνθρώπινος, η, ον, also ος, ον Pl. Lg. 737b:—

children.definition: of, from, or belonging to man, human, ἀ. βίος Philol. 11, cf. Hdt. 7.46; ἅπαν τὸ ἀ. all mankind, Id. 1.86; τὸ ἀ. γένος (v.l. φῦλον) Antipho 4.1.2, Pl. Phd. 82b; ἀ. κίνδυνοι, opp. θεῖοι, And. 1.139; ἀ. δίκη Lys. 6.20; ἀ. τεκμήρια, opp. omens, Antipho 5.81; τἀνθρώπινα human affairs, Pl. Tht. 170b, Arist. EN 1102b3 (v.l. -ικά) ἀνθρώπινόν τι παθεῖν die, IG 5(2), 266.20 ( Mantinea, i B. C.), cf. PPetr. 1p.33 (iii B. C.), PRyl. 153.39 (ii A. D.); so ἐάν τι τῶν ἀ. περί τινα γένηται Epicur. Fr. 217.

data.quote: ἐάν τι τῶν ἀ. περί τινα γένηται

children.definition: human, suited to man, ἀνθρωπίνη δόξα fallible, human understanding, Pl. Sph. 229a; οὐκ ἀ. ἀμαθία super-human, monstrous folly, Id. Lg. 737b, etc.; ἀ. καὶ μετρία σκῆψις D. 21.41; οὐ χρὴ ἀνθρώπινα φρονεῖν ἄνθρωπον ὄντα Arist. EN 1177b32; ἀ. νοῦς Men. 482; ἀ. τὸ γεγενημένον X. Cyr. 5.4.19.

data.quote: οὐ χρὴ ἀνθρώπινα φρονεῖν ἄνθρωπον ὄντα

children.definition: ἀνθρώπινα, τά, secular revenues, SIG 527.133; secular rites, opp. θῖνα, Leg.Gort. 10.43.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adv. ἀνθρωπίνως, ἁμαρτάνειν commit human, i.e. venial, errors, Th. 3.40; ἀνθρωπινώτερον more within the range of human faculty, Pl. Cra. 392b, D. 18.252; ἀνθρωπίνως ἐκλογίζεσθαι, i.e. with fellow-feeling, And. 2.6; humanely, gently, D. 23.70; ἀ. χρὴ τὰς τύχας φέρειν with moderation, Men. 816; εὐτυχίαν D.S. 1.60.—Of the three forms, ἀνθρώπειος is used exclusively in Trag. and generally in Th. (but cf. 1.22); ἀνθρώπινος prevails in Comedy and in Prose from Pl. downwds. (though he uses ἀνθρώπειος no less frequently); ἀνθρωπικός is freq. in Arist.

senses.definition: = sq., E. Cyc. 185, Anaxandr. 34; paltry fellow, ὦ πόνηρʼ ἀνθρώπια Ar. Pax 263, cf. X. Mem. 2.3.16, Cyr. 5.1.14, D. 18.242.

children.definition: Dim. of ἄνθρωπος, manikin, E. Cyc. 316, Pl. R. 495c; with a shade of contempt, Id. Phdr. 243a, cf. Luc. Pisc. 17; ἰδιώτας ἀ. κωμῳδῶν Ar. Pax 751.
humanity, Aristipp. ap. D.L. 2.70.
in the language of men, S. Fr. 827, cf. Sch. Od. 6.125, Ps.-Callisth. 3.17.
practise cannibalism, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.186.
cannibalism, Zeno Stoic. 1.59 (pl.).
man-eating, Ph. 2.423.
speaking manʼs language, of the parrot, Arist. HA 597b27.
a place for fulling men, comic name for a bath, ap. Clem.Al. Paed. 3.9.
beget, produce men, Ph. 2.494.
begetting of men, title of play by Antiphanes, POxy. 427; origin of man, J. Ap. 1.8.
painter of men, Plin. HN 35.113.
man-god, i.e. deified man, E. Rh. 971; semi-devil, Procop. Arc. 12.
bitten by a man, Dsc. 1.125, Antig. ap. Philum. Ven. 5.1.

like a man, in human shape, τύπος Hdt. 2.86; θεὸν ἀ. οὐδένα γενέσθαι ib. 142; θηρίον Phryn. PS p.6B.; θεοί Arist. Metaph. 997b10, Phld. Piet. 15, al.; πίθηκοι Arist. HA 502a24; of zodiacal signs, Ptol. Tetr. 145. Adv. -δῶς D.L. 10.139.
like a man, Hsch. Prooem.
humanitus, Gloss.
hunting of men, Pl. Sph. 223b.
bold as a man, opp. θυμολέων, Plu. Bruta anim. 2.988d.
human sacrifice, Plu. Herod. 857a, al.: in pl., Def.orac. ib. 417c, Str. 4.4.5, Pallas ap. Porph. Abst. 2.56.
offer human sacrifices, Ph. 2.28, Porph. Abst. 2.27.
belonging to the care or government of men: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) politics, Them. Or. 15.186d:—also ἀνθρωπο-κόμος, ον, Anon. in Rh. 3.607 W.
E. Hec. 260; offer human sacrifice, Phylarch. 63:— Subst. ἀνθρωπο-κτονία, ἡ, Porph. Abst. 2.55, Hld. 10.7.
murdering men, homicide, E. IT 389, 1 Ep.Jo. 3.15, Ev.Jo. 8.44.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀνθρωπόκτονος βορά feeding on slaughtered men, E. Cyc. 127.
man-worshipper, Νεστόριος ὁ ἀ. Cod.Just. 1.1.5.
plague of men, murderous, Suid.
greedy of human flesh, μυῖα Herm. ap. Stob. 1.41.68.
describe or represent in the form of man, Ph. 1.282:— Pass., ib. 181.
speaking of man, i.e. fond of personal conversation, Arist. EN 1125a5.
one who cooks human flesh, Luc. Asin. 6.
imitating men, Ps.-Plu. Fluv. 14.3.
of human form, θεός Epicur. Fr. 353, cf. Str. 17.1.28, Ph. 1.15, Corn. ND 27, Procop. Arc. 18; ζῴδια Ptol. Tetr. 79, 181.
feeding men: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) Pl. Plt. 266e.
with human understanding, intelligent, πίθηκοι Ael. NA 16.10: Sup. -νούστατος Str. 15.1.29.
to have the concept or idea of a man, Plu. Col. 2.1120d.
humanity, Alciphr. 2.1.
to have human feelings, ἄνθρωπος ὢν ἀ. Ph. 1.134.
with human feelings, Ph. 1.182, al. Adv. -θῶς, λέγεσθαι, of the gods, Hermog. Id. 2.10.
fashioner of men, Ph. 1.652.
make, form man or men, Simp. in Cat. 333.6.
making of man or men, Luc. Prom. 5, 17.
making men, of a portrait-sculptor, opp. θεοποιός, Luc. Philops. 18, 20; γυνὴ -ποιὸν ὑπούργημα Secund. Sent. 8; ἀ. χώρα Simp. in Epict. p.64D.
city of men, title of Menippean satire by Varro.
man-destroyer, Drawcansir, a comedy of Strattis.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ael. NA 12.34.

definition: ἄνθρωπος, ὁ, Att. crasis ἅνθρωπος, Ion. ὥνθρωπος, for ὁ ἄνθρ-:—

children.definition: man, both as a generic term and of individuals, Hom. etc., opp. gods, ἀθανάτων τε θεῶν χαμαὶ ἐρχομένων τʼ ἀνθρώπων Il. 5.442, etc.; πρὸς ἠοίων ἢ ἑσπερίων ἀνθρώπων the men of the east or of the west, Od. 8.29; even of the dead in the Isles of the Blest, ib. 4.565; κόμπος οὐ κατʼ ἄνθρωπον A. Th. 425, cf. S. Aj. 761.

data.quote: ἀθανάτων τε θεῶν χαμαὶ ἐρχομένων τʼ ἀνθρώπων

children.definition: Pl. uses it both with and without the Art. to denote man generically, ὁ ἄ. θείας μετέσχε μοίρας Prt. 322a; οὕτω . . εὐδαιμονέστατος γίγνεται ἄ. R. 619b, al.; ὁ ἄ. the ideal man, humanity, ἀπώλεσας τὸν ἄ., οὐκ ἐπλήρωσας τὴν ἐπαγγελίαν Arr. Epict. 2.9.3.

data.quote: ἀπώλεσας τὸν ἄ., οὐκ ἐπλήρωσας τὴν ἐπαγγελίαν

children.definition: mankind, ἀνθρώπων . . ἀνδρῶν ἠδὲ γυναικῶν Il. 9.134; ἐν τῷ μακρῷ . . ἀνθρώπων χρόνῳ S. Ph. 306; ἐξ ἀνθρώπων γίγνεσθαι depart this life, Paus. 4.26.5, cf. Philostr. VA 8.31.

children.label: b
children.definition: Sup. to increase its force, δεινότατον τῶν ἐν ἀνθρώποις ἁπάντων D. 53.2; ὁ ἄριστος ἐν ἀνθρώποις ὄρτυξ the best quail in the world, Pl. Ly. 211e; freq. without a Prep., μάλιστα, ἥκιστα ἀνθρώπων, most or least of all, Hdt. 1.60, Pl. Lg. 629a, Prt. 361e; ἄριστά γʼ ἀ., ὀρθότατα ἀ., Id. Tht. 148b, 195b, etc.

children.label: c
children.definition: τὰ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων πράγματα ‘all the trouble in the world’, ib. 170e; γραφὰς τὰς ἐξ ἀνθρώπων ἐγράφετο Lys. 13.73; αἱ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων πληγαί Aeschin. 1.59; πάντα τὰ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κακὰ ἔλεγε D.C. 57.23.

data.quote: πάντα τὰ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων κακὰ ἔλεγε

children.definition: Subst., like ἀνήρ, ἄ. ὁδίτης Il. 16.263; πολίτας ἀ. D. 22.54; with names of nations, πόλις Μερόπων ἀνθρώπων h.Ap. 42; in Att. freq. in a contemptuous sense, ἄ. ὑπογραμματεύς, ἄ. γόης, ἄ. συκοφάντης, Lys. 30.28, Aeschin. 2.153,183; ἄ. ἀλαζών X. Mem. 1.7.2; ἄ. ὑφάντης Pl. Phd. 87b; Μενίππου, Καρός τινος ἀνθρώπου D. 21.175; ἄ. βασιλεύς Ev.Matt. 22.2.
ἅνθρωπος or ὁ ἄνθρωπος alone, the man, the fellow, Pl. Prt. 314e, Phd. 117e; ὡς ἀστεῖος ὁ ἄ., with slight irony, ib. 116d, al.; with a sense of pity, D. 21.91.
ἄνθρωπε or ὤνθρωπε sirrah! you sir! Hdt. 3.63, 8.125, and freq. in Pl., but in Trag. only S. Aj. 791, 1154; simply, brother, POxy. 215.1, Diog.Oen. 2.
slave, ἂν ἄ. ᾖ Philem. 22; ἄ. ἐμός Gal. 14.649; ὁ ἄ. τῆς ἁμαρτίας or ἀνομίας 2 Ep.Thess. 2.3; ἄ. τοῦ Θεοῦ 1 Ep.Tim. 6.11; but τιθέναι τινὰ ἐν ἀνθρώποις make a man of, of a freed slave, Herod. 5.15.
ἄ. ἄ. any one, Hebraism in LXX Le. 17.3 (cf. ἀνήρ VI.8); ἄ. like Germ. man ‘one’, 1 Ep.Cor. 4.1, al.
plaster, ἡ διὰ σάνδυκος ἄ. καλουμένη Aët. 15.43.

children.label: II
children.definition: woman, Pi. P. 4.98, Hdt. 1.60, Isoc. 18.52, Arist. EN 1148b20; contemptuously, of female slaves, Antipho 1.17, Is. 6.20, etc.; with a sense of pity, D. 19.197.—Prop. opp. θηρίον, cf. ἀνήρ; but opp. γυνή, Aeschin. 3.137; ἀπὸ ἀνθρώπου ἕως γυναικός LXX 1 Es. 9.40, etc.
slay men, E. Hec. 260.
abstract humanity, Ph. 1.206, S.E. M. 7.273, Vett.Val. 346.29, Plot. 6.1.10, Dam. Pr. 58.
nourishing men, Hsch.
eat human flesh, Hdt. 4.106, Porph. Abst. 2.57; of carnivora, Arist. HA 594a29.
cannibalism, Arist. Pol. 1338b20, Phld. Sto. Herc. 339.14, Porph. Abst. 2.57: in pl., Plu. Luc. 11.
like cannibals, Eust. 634.59.
man-eating, Antiph. 68.12, Arist. HA 501b1, Heraclit. Incred. 31:—esp. of cannibal tribes, Str. 4.5.4, etc.
destroying men, gloss on βροτολοιγός, Sch. Il. 5.31.
of manʼs nature, οὐκ ἀνθρωποφυέας ἐνόμισαν τοὺς θεούς Hdt. 1.131; Κένταυροι D.S. 4.69.
herb of mercury (= πενταδάκτυλον, ἑρμοδάκτυλον, Ps.- Dsc.), Cat. Cod.Astr. 8(3).162:—also ἀνθρωπό-χειρ, ὁ, ib. 7.234.
Lacon. for ἄνθρωπος II, Hsch.

definition: Ἀνθρωφηρακλῆς, -έος, ὁ, title of play by Pherecrates, Phot. p.145R.

children.definition: abuse one another, abuse in turn, E. Ph. 620 ( Pass.), Plu. Per. 26, Luc. DMeretr. 33, etc.
counter-abuse, Mich. in EN 54.9.
bark or bay in answer, Ael. NA 4.19.

definition: ἀνθύλλιον, τό, Dim. of ἄνθος, M.Ant. 4.20, Dsc. 2.183.

children.definition: Cressa cretica, Dsc. 3.136.
herb ivie, Ajuga Iva, ibid., Plin. HN 26.84.

definition: ἄνθυλλον, τό, = foreg. [ἀνθυλλίς] I, Ps.- Dsc. 3.136, Plin. HN 21.175.

children.definition: bring to trial or indict in turn, Th. 3.70.
rejoin, reply, A.D. Pron. 53.21, al.:— Pass., τὸ -αγόμενον, -αχθησόμενον, Id. Synt. 118.1, 121.22.

children.label: b
children.definition: substitute, ib. 12.9, etc.
lead under in turn, αἰχμαλώτους ὑπὸ τὸ ζυγόν D.C. Fr. 36.22; but in Med., bring over, τινὰς ἐς εὔνοιαν ib. 35.10.
withdraw in turn, ἀνθυπῆγε Μαρδόνιος Aristid. 1.146J.
reply, A.D. Synt. 19.12, al.
listen to in turn, τινός Nicol. Prog. 6.10 in Rh. 1.314W.

children.label: II
children.definition: correspond, answer to, Iamb. in Nic. p.21P.
substitution of one case for another, Demetr. Eloc. 60, A.D. Synt. 204.27, al.

substitute, esp. in Rhet., substitute one case for another, Demetr. Eloc. 59, cf. A.D. Synt. 232.2; of interchange of moods, in Pass., ib. 211.19:— Med., receive in exchange, θνητὸν ἀθανάτου βίον Ph. 2.440.
meet, reply to objections, πρός τινα Longin. 18.1.
to be set over against, of ἀντίστοιχα, Stoic. ap. Plu. Sollert. 2.960b.
proconsulate, CIG (add.)3841f ( Aezani), BCH 11.110 (Epist. Hadriani), Hdn. 7.5.2, Just. Nov. 8.1: pl., ib. 26.5 Intr.
to be proconsul, Plu. Comp.Dem.Cic. 3, Act.Ap. 18.12, Hdn. 7.5.2.
proconsularis, Just. Nov. 30.1.
proconsular, ἐξουσία D.C. 58.7.
ἀ. δεκαδαρχία the body of military tribunes which took the place of the consulate, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.277f.
proconsul, Lat. pro consule, Plb. 28.5.6, Act.Ap. 13.7, etc., freq. in Inscrr. as SIG 684.3, and Pap. as Sammelb. 3924.32 (i A. D.); στρατηγὸς ἀ. SIG 704 K, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., proconsular, ἐξουσία D.H. 9.16; ἀρχή Id. 11.62.
yield in turn or mutually, τινί Plu. Cor. 18, D.C. 45.8.
a mutual yielding, Plu. Sol. 4.
surpass in turn, J. AJ 16.7.2.
to be haughty in return, August. ap. Suet. vit. Horat. [fr. 40, 30]
insinuate oneself into, creep upon in turn, τινά Anon. Prog. in Rh. 1.601 W.

children.label: II
children.definition: take the place of, A.D. Synt. 95.9, 112.6.
serve in turn, τινί Arist. EN 1133a4, 1170b25.
promise in return, Sch. Ar. Eq. 694.
bring objections in turn, retort, Aeschin. 3.209.

children.label: II
children.definition: substitute fraudulently, Ph. 2.630.
brought forward as an instance in opposition, Phld. D. 1.16.
answer in return, Hdt. 6.86.γʹ.

children.label: II
children.definition: put on or pretend in turn, ὀργήν Luc. Dom. 30.
leave on the other side, f.l. in Ph. 2.505 ( Pass.).
compensate, Gloss.
charge against, deduct, PPetr. 3p.149.
compensation, Gloss.
make a counter-affidavit, in Med., D. 48.25, 58.43.
suspect mutually, ἀλλήλους D.C. 45.8: abs., Aen. Tact. 24.11 (cj.):— Pass., ἀνθυποπτεύεται . . πλέον ἕξειν he is met by the suspicion that . ., Th. 3.43.
make countermines, Aen. Tact. 37.5, Polyaen. 6.17.
countermining, Ph. Bel. 100.22 (pl.).
convertibility of substance, Dam. Pr. 158.
recur, of an illness, Poll. 3.107; return, Olymp. in Mete. 148.1, Pall. in Hp.Fract. 12.276C.; turn round upon, Ps.-Callisth. 2.29; turn back, ib. 31, al.
return, of a clyster, Sever. Clyst. 25.
Steph. in Hp. 2.279D.
maintain by way of rejoinder, Ulp. ad D. 23.88.

reply to the ὑποτίμησις (q. v.), Poll. 8.150.
reply to ὑποτίμησις, Rh. 5.7 W.
return a kindness, ἀ. τινὶ τοῦτο τὸ ἂν δεηθῇ Hdt. 3.133; χάριν S. Fr. 339; αἰσχρά τινι E. Hipp. 999; τι καθʼ αὑτὸν Corn. ND 15.

children.definition: service done in return, Anon. in Rh. 109.1.
returning of a kindness, Hsch.
reveal in turn, CIG 4958 ( Egypt).
reply, rejoin, opp. πυνθάνομαι, D.H. Dem. 54, cf. Hermog. Inv. 4.14, S.E. M. 7.44.

children.definition: use a word or phrase in reply to a question, in Pass., A.D. Pron. 24.17, Synt. 73.6.

reply, opp. πεῦσις, D.H. Dem. 54; esp. reply to a supposed objection, Quint. Inst. 9.3.87, Hermog. Inv. 3.4, Ulp. ad D. 3.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: reply, A.D. Synt. 72.26.

retiring in turn, εἰς τὸ ἐκτός Plu. 2.903d.
Alex.Aphr. in Top. 545.16.
take away again or in turn, lamb. in Nic. p.28P., Porph. in Ptol. 194:— Pass., LXX Le. 27.18, PLond. ined. 2361 v (iii B. C.), D.C. 48.33, Procl. Hyp. 4.12.
